items.title: Humans and neural networks show similar patterns of transfer and interference during continual learning
items.author: Christopher Summerfield
items.content: When learning new tasks, both humans and artificial neural networks face a trade-off between reusing prior knowledge to learn faster and avoiding the disruption of earlier learning. This study shows that people and artificial neural networks have similar patterns of transfer and interference and vary in how they balance this trade-off.

items.title: Spontaneous brain regional dynamics contribute to generalizable brain–behaviour associations
items.author: Bing Liu
items.content: Tian et al. reveal that rich temporal dynamics within individual brain regions form stable individual-specific ‘barcodes’, advancing generalizable brain-wide association studies beyond traditional connectivity measures.

items.title: Bringing natural ecosystems into the bioecological model of human development
items.author: Pamela Morris-Perez
items.content: The bioecological model of human development is among the most influential frameworks in the social sciences. We argue that it is time to integrate natural ecosystems into this model. This approach will shape research, practice and policy to promote both healthy human development and an environmentally sustainable future.

items.title: Attention on social media depends more on how you express yourself than on who you are
items.author: Weidong Wang
items.content: This study shows that how you express yourself is more influential than who you are in attracting attention on social media. Attention is easier to acquire than to sustain.

items.title: The nature of the relation between mental well-being and ill-being
items.author: Tilmann von Soest
items.content: Tamnes et al. explore the complex relationship between ill-being—including mental and behavioural disorders—and mental well-being.

items.title: Bridging the empathy perception gap fosters social connection
items.author: Jamil Zaki
items.content: Young adults face rising loneliness and mental health challenges. In a study of 5,192 undergraduates, Pei et al. find that perceiving peers as empathic is related to better well-being. Students, however, underestimate peers’ empathy. Two field experiments offered simple interventions that reduced this empathy perception gap and increased social behaviour and connection.

items.title: Changing empathy perceptions improves connection
items.author: Simone Shamay-Tsoory
items.content: Can loneliness be reduced by changing perceptions of empathy? A large-scale study by Pei et al. shows that people tend to underestimate others’ empathy, and correcting this misconception fosters social connection and increases the formation of friendships.

items.title: An interdisciplinary linked-lives approach to individual differences in social behaviour
items.author: Mitja D. Back
items.content: Individuality in social behaviour is of interest across several academic fields, yet there are many barriers to interdisciplinary efforts. In this Perspective, Kuper et al propose an integrative, interdisciplinary approach, and detail their recommendations for researchers interested in this topic.
